FYI for anyone wondering: they got the definition of heat death very wrong. It doesn't just mean it's all really cold. It means there's nothing able to do any work or make any more entropy at all.

Because of that wrong definition, they also have the order of events relating to heat death wrong.

It's not "Heat death, therefore there's only black dwarves and black holes" ...no, black holes and black dwarves still have mass, movement, angular momentum, hawking radiation etc etc. They can still do work, and the universe will still be a very dynamic and changing place (though over huge timescales).

Heat death is the term for AFTER that, i.e. when even all the black holes have evaporated away, everything has smoothed out, full entropy is reached, and the universe is completely static with no ability for anything else to ever happen, where the concept of time itself then becomes meaningless. THAT is heat death of the universe.

The heat death at the end is not an absolute certainty. We know so little about dark matter that it's difficult to predict the next million trillion years based in the last few billion years. While the big freeze is certainly the prevailing theory based on what we know now, it is entirely possible that the expansion stops, slows down, reverses or possibly even rips everything (including atoms) apart. We simply don't know enough or haven't been around long enough to know for sure.

This theory that I (RyanVD) made is called the naked star hypothesis (it’s not kind of naked you’re thinking about) because it’s a process of whenever a star loses its outer layers, through many incredibly violent events, such as supernova explosion, being vampired by other stars and even getting blasted by a gamma ray bursts or a random burst from a feeding black hole (often called a quasar), and many other factors,

many types of stars (including high mass stars and white dwarfs) can lose their outer layers(sometimes called envelope),but the event has be violent enough to strip the stars outer layers,

The type of star from this hypothesis is similar to the carbon type white dwarf from a dying low or medium mass star, except its mainly made of hydrogen instead of carbon and oxygen, and this type of white dwarf is basically a stellar cinder (or exposed core) of a star that has lost its outer layers, mainly from a gamma ray burst or a powerful supernova explosion is powerful enough to strip the star’s outer layers.

Black dwarfs may exist in our time as white dwarfs that have lost their outer layers, by incredibly violent and powerful events, such as supernovae explosions and gamma ray bursts, or binary interaction with dead stars such as neutron stars and black holes?
And gamma ray bursts are one of the most common and powerful events, that can strip and even vaporizes some stars including giant stars, and even white dwarfs, and since gamma ray bursts usually happens once every day, all around the universe, and this means that dozens or even hundreds of white dwarf stars are being blasted off, into black dwarfs, every single day!?
And once a white dwarf star becomes a black dwarf, it will never change back into a white dwarf, even if the black dwarf sucks material from another star.

And don’t forget to mention that since white dwarfs are so hot, and gravitationally powerful enough to burn and rip planets apart,into a ring of debris,
And it’s that white dwarfs can be even hotter than they really are, by sucking material from a companion star (such as a red dwarf), and the material from the companion star can truly heat the white dwarf to millions of degrees F, and possibly increase the white dwarfs spin,

And in other words the planet needs to be as close as earth is to the sun, and white dwarfs are much hotter than Wolf Rayet stars but dimmer than sun like stars,
So on the livable planet that orbits a white dwarf, the day time side looks like the night, and the planet will still be warm by the intensity of the radiation from the white dwarf star, and white dwarfs are the only dead stars that can host livable planets (as in planets with life).
But as long as the white dwarf is not in the binary pair.

While humans will likely die out before mastering space travel, and effective space travel will probably not occur without unlocking the mysteries of gravitational force, in the unlikely event that humanity can unlock those mysteries, it may be possible to prevent the heat death of the universe.  What may seem wildly impossible now, the  terraforming (for lack of a better word) of entire galaxies may be a way to keep the initial heat death of the universe at bay, and prolong the lifespan of energy forces with enough planning and execution.  While this is all incredibly unlikely, given the amount of time we would have to work with if humanity ever does master space travel and gravitational force, it isn't entirely impossible.

The notion of a dying universe is nonsense. Everything is relative, including temperature or time. Living beings of the future 100 billion of our present "years" from now might cosider our era as part of the big bang because compared to their era our era is incredibly hot and incredibly fast, just as we view the era 13 billion of our "years" before us as incredibly hot and fast and part of the big bang. Things will keep slowing down, temperatures will keep dropping but again, both time and temperature are relative to the observer. From the POV of a distant future observer our livespans might look like 10^-12 "seconds" measured in his own future time scales.

"Right now, we happen to exist at an excellent time."
Ya right.

Heat Death of the Universe is just the scariest thing I can imagine. The Big Bang started the universe with an explosive heat, creating reactions, creating new matter, and rules of how things work. Heat Death is... nobody will be there. Just... a void. A void of lifeless ice balls, black dwarfs, and black holes eating up what remains.

Thing is, there are rules. Some matter and elements don't work well together, causing a reaction. The only hope that we have at that point is that another reaction occurs, causing heat, hopefully sparking something new. If a black hole gathers enough matter and elements, wouldn't that cause something to happen?

...or was that how the Big Bang started? One final black hole in the previous incarnation of the universe gathered all the possible matter, reaching critical mass, and exploded, unleashing the matter back into the universe.

Would something like that be possible?

Everything does come to an end eventually. It's just that wrapping your head around the scope of it all is mind blowing.

Actually in black dwarves theres tones and tons of ready-to-fuse easy degenerate matter that will trigger at the first shot of hot H, and the universe have plenty, everywhere.
Also its ultra dense He crust/mantle is unstable outside its pressures, so a hard enough hit would trigger a local mmini nova, life could appear in the nebula and slowly populate its surface, fusing UDHe for life, or civilizations survive by slowly fusing away them... And the iron stars can slowly form a neutron core, slowly turning into a cold pulsar, that eventually collapses into a black hole, that radiates away... This would give civilizations enough time to break enthropy just by waiting for infinite Improbability events, assuming they can live in such energy poor eviroments... mabe SFIA has to make another civs at the end of time episode...

To give you an idea, the hypothetical iron stars won’t arrive until 10^1500 years. After that, if quantum tunneling is right, even iron stars will fall into eventual black holes in 10^10^76 years after even more quantum tunneling. After that, only black holes remain. Then, in what is simply called “the dark era” (10^10^120), black holes fade due to radiation and the universe expands even more until the theoretical “Big Rip”. This may be a singularity event where space-time gets ripped apart and space is left for a Big Bang but it’s uncertain.

I want to bring up some interesting thoughts regarding black dwarfs.

They will go through a period of cooling down to near absolute 0 from a few hundred degrees kelvin. Now, at a certain point, these temperatures would cross around that of earth’s. The sphere will be mostly crystalized by this point. Now, since materials exist on the spheres like oxygen and carbon, and even a little hydrogen, there could be traces of liquid water and certain chemicals. It may be unlikely, but some form of life could emerge from it.

This video's pace didn't allow them to go into what a White Dwarf is actually made of. So I'll do my best at a quick explanation for the curious...
(tl;dr - free floating sub-atomic particles spawned mainly from carbon and oxygen)
As mentioned they are what remains of the core of a small-to-medium sized red giant star after its fusion sequence. Once it's fused all of its hydrogen into helium, it begins to fuse helium into mainly carbon and oxygen. Once there is insufficient temperature and pressure to sustain fusion, it sheds its outer layers to reveal a core of inert (non-reacting but still very hot) carbon and oxygen. Because there is no nuclear energy being generated, there is no heat to push back against gravitational collapse. This being the case, the core collapses and is pressurized into a mass of what's called 'degenerate matter' - essentially free protons, neutrons and electrons which are not bound by chemical bonds into atoms or molecules.
The step beyond this only happens to massive red giants, where their gravitational mass is so huge that upon gravitational collapse its protons and electrons (positively and negatively charged subatomic particles) fuse to form neutrons (neutrally charged subatomic particles); the heaviest of the three. This is called a Neutron Star, the densest object we can currently observe, with a density of atomic nuclei itself.
All of that being said; it is not really necessary in order to understand and enjoy the video. That's where Kerzgesagt really......shines. Knowing just how much detail to include, and what is extraneous technical mumbo jumbo that just slows down the pace and makes 95% of viewers' eyes glaze over.

Many have commented that they are depressed after watching this. To me though, the ultimate fate of the universe, whether this is all a simulation, and other such big questions really don't change anything about how I live my life. All we can do is to steer things in a better direction using whatever talents we've been gifted with, whether by a higher power or simply through dumb luck and random distribution of traits. WE set the tone within whatever minuscule sliver of time and space we inhabit.
Add value to the lives of others in whatever ways you can. Treat our world and those living within it the way you'd like to be treated; We're all just people. The Dalai Lama says the right answer to a problem is the compassionate answer, and we should treat people and the world with compassion whenever possible. He follows up by reminding us that it is ALWAYS possible. And oh yeah, have a few laughs along the way too. That's what I'D do anyway! And I would 100% be in a position to know after all; For I am some guy on the internet!

Ok, I'm no expert, but here's what y'all need to do, as far as i understand:
1. Create or find a suitable black hole
2. Elongate it's singularity
3. Put a lot of exotic matter with negative mass (actually possible) inside
You end up with a wormhole that leads to an expanding bubble of space that isn't accessible by any other means than this wormhole.
4. You put enough mass inside
5. You collapse the wormhole if you want, but that's optional
You end up with a brand new universe. That sounds complicated, but if you hadn't figured out how to do it in 10^81 years, i don't pity you or your civilization.

"If we could find a white dwarf with the right conditions to settle around, we could have a home for many billions of years..." "Humanity's last home, right before the death of the universe" ... "which may make them humanity's last refuge"...

It's always amusing to me that anyone considers human life beyond a few thousand years from now. We have only yet existed as modern humans for only a few thousand years (200Ky anatomically, but likely <70Ky intellectually). After much less than one million years, humanity will have evolved and changed into species that would no longer be considered homo sapiens sapiens – the you and me beings as we are now all over the world. After millions of years, any descendants of humans would be unrecognizable as humans. And, that is IF we survive that long. Natural extinction-level mega-catastrophes are bound to happen by then, and – even more likely – our own man-made planet-wide disasters are likely to throw us back into a stone-age existence much sooner, like within hundreds or thousands of years.* To talk about what humanity will do when the sun extinguishes in billions of years is preposterous! Discussions of what we can do when the universe approaches heat death in trillions of years... well, that is just an unfathomable time span, indistinguishable from eternity to us humans. Let's face it – it is not just your life that is but a mere instant of cosmic time, but the entire existence of the human race is much less than a blink in the cosmos.

* Don't count on humans persisting by finding safe harbor within other worlds. Though we are on track to sending humans to other planets and moons within our solar system, since faster-than-light travel is not physically possible, we are not likely to colonize beyond our own solar system. Human colonies and outposts outside of Earth will require the most sophisticated technology for life support, making them way more fragile than life on Earth, since any critical failure will spell doom. Reaching another star system would be a voyage of multiple generations, during which the pioneers would be highly vulnerable and helpless. Plus we can't be certain that the target destination is hospitable enough, nor would it be feasible to change destinations mid-course. Then there's the limitation that terraforming another planet would take dozens if not hundreds of human lifespans, and even by then the target planet would not be as livable as the Earth we have evolved within. Sorry – I'd love to be more optimistic, but these are the realities.

This reminds me of VERY theoretical concept I watched a video on describing the absolute longest humanity could survive. In theory we could "survive" as consciousness in a giant supercomputer orbiting the stable orbit of a black hole, using (I believe) hawkings radiation or some such as the only energy source. Humanity would live in "hibernation" for billions of years during the heat death of the universe until the universe was sufficiently cold enough, and then the supercomputer could run on comparatively extremely low energy consumption .

Due to the time dilation near a black hole it would also buy humanity a LOT of time relative to the "normal" timer ticking down the true death of the universe when even the black holes have dissipated. The vast energy consumption that would be required for this supercomputer housing potentially billions of complex consciousness in a realistic paradise simulation only running on practically no energy could be theoretically solved due to perception of time. The computer could run at 1/100 the speed of your average computer, computing a second of the virtual worlds reality in a million years, and everyone could still potentially live for millions of years from your perspective in the virtual world.

I think the main problem discussed was that you would need to make the computer out of materials that could remain operational for billions of years even in the most optimistic situation where nothing interferes with it in the vacuum of space.

I am by no means educated on the subject so I may have butchered some (or all) aspects of this theoretical situation but that is what I remember.

What if, once everything in the universe becomes just black dwarfs and black holes, it all begins to drift, as the evidence shows it will. Eventually, it all congeals at a single spot (after a lot of drifting and a lot of time). Black holes pretty much end up competing and trying to be the biggest until one black hole's gravity presses all the matter and energy in the universe that survived back down into a singularity. Then, this singularity may expand, creating another big bang and starting the universe anew.

No proof of this and really no way to prove it, but it could be the case.

Even after all stars become white dwarves, there may still be some hope before and even during the black dwarf phase: the white dwarf limit. If for some reason a white dwarf exceeds 1.4 solar masses the entire object will instantly undergo fusion, causing a white dwarf supernova that will convert all of its mass into energy and fling any surrounding mass away at incredible speeds. Usually this only happens when a white dwarf forms in a binary star system, but any mass past the white dwarf limit will do. This could even happen to black dwarves, meaning that they could very well collide and keep the universe running for quite a while longer.

Interesting thought: What if the inhabitants of every universe become the "God" or creators, of the next? I'll explain.
Say we reach a level of technology unheard of from our current day. Say we become so advanced, so energy efficient, that our kind could live on essentially forever even without the need of using stars and the sort. Imagine that in this universe of heat death, the advanced species present use their technology to start putting every dead star equidistant from one another using technology we could only dream of. They then use this technology to send each of these massive dead stars hurtling towards one another, colliding at the exact same moment, creating what is essentially the next big bang. From then they can just continue growing and observing and existing as they do, watching the universe as it develops and goes through the same stages as before, only to do it all over again when the next heat death occurs.
Ain't that food for thought.

I don't feel pointless while watching these sorts of videos, though. I might be a special snowflake that isn't discouraged by this sorta crap, but I'm no master physicist, or scientist, or enviromentalist, so that might be why. But hear me out though.

Yeah sure, we might be insignificant, but hey, so is every other living thing. It's not like we aren't the only insignificant thing. Every race is insignificant, from dinosaurs to aliens. But just because we are insignificant doesn't mean we can't have a self suited purpose. I mean, since when do sea bass give a fuck about what humans think? They're just trying to live their lives. Sure, we might fish and eventually drive them extinct, but does that mean their efforts are in vain? No. They tried their best, but if they couldn't do it, well, nobody really expected them to. Humans are advanced and highly intelligent compared to fish, so them winning the struggle isn't a likely outcome, but its a nice one that deserves a shot. Maybe that solution is retreating and adapting to the deep seas of the Antarctic, taking advantage of humans not being able to traverse the ocean there as well as their former homes. You never know how far you'll go untill you try. Well, you might have an idea or prediction, but ideas change and predictions do too. Now, take that little visual, and zoom out more, with humanity being the fish, and universe being us. Nobody is expecting us to become genius survivors and become galatical emperors, because I bet that alot of civilizations destroyed themselves in the process. The universe is big, and can wipe us out any second. Does that mean that humanity shouldn't try, though? No.

Imagine if every ape killed themselves. Well, would that solve anything? No, by killing themselves, they're just cementing their fate of becoming an extinct race earlier than what they could be. But what if they lived longer? Why, little did they know, they would become humans; more smarter and able than their former selves. Apes sucked back then, and humanity might suck right now, but we are constantly changing, and have alot of room to grow. Hell, we'll probably become something else entirely in due time that's better suited for the more newer challenges of the universe. Think of it like leveling up in a video game. Of course, that's because life is very similar to a game, right? Just a very large one with infinite possibilities and consequences around every corner.

I dunno, think of life as a game like...flappy bird. Yeah, sure, the dead trend that died 4 years ago or so. Forgive me, I'm braindead.

Anyways, you are going to lose your streak sometime, since you are human and you make errors. But despite knowing that, you still try to get a higher score. Why is that so? Well, it's because its fun to try. Life might not be fun alot of the time, but hey, you are already given the chance to live in the first place. So why not try your best to become sucessful and help others become sucessful too? Nothing is stopping you from making the world a better place.

And hey, we always talk about superior alien races waltzing over to our system and wrecking the fuck out of us. But how did they begin? Of course they had to have an upbringing made of trial and error, and maybe they didn't need many errors to figure some things out and got lucky with the first few tries. Same thing with us. Nobody is born knowing everything. Hell, humanity is more like a toddler right now. There's alot of room for growth, and everything we do now can be improved. Technology is increasing exponentially, and the first mars mission isn't that far away. Young teenagers right now may be in their late 60's by then, but during their lifetime, they went from not even thinking about the possibility of iphones and flatscreen tvs to acknowledging the terrors of space and cyber warfare. Technology is growing exponentially, so every era might eventually just take 20 years to come and go eventually.

There's alot of time to do things, so don't stress out on this sorta crap. Its ok to be a little ignorant sometimes.

I think that you are forgetting something important. Energy cannot be created and it cannot be destroyed, it can only change form and regardless of form, energy just is even in a state of matter. This pokes some notable holes in The Big Bang Theory and it definitely doesn't jive with the idea that we are eventually headed towards the death of the universe. The idea that all that is just exploded into existence and that nothingness will follow the implosion is predicated on the assumption that energy was literally created by nothing and is ultimately fated to return to nothing. These ideas hold more of a claim to celebrity than they do facts. It's a comfortable mindset to be agreeable to them because if you argue or question then you become the center of a judgmental spotlight and must defend yourself immediately. 4:05 YO! I did some math. According to this video, white dwarfs might shine for 10 billion times longer than the current age of the universe. That's a long time to evolve, if we live that long..... which I'm guessing we won't. But anyway, the whole life span of a white dwarf is 10 billion times the age of the universe. To give perspective on how long that is, imagine that amount of time compressed in to a person's life span of 100 years. Where would we be in life? I did the math, there are only 3.1 billion seconds in a hundred years, so if the universe was person, it would be less than half a second old, if it were to live one hundred years. It would still be half way inside a vagina. Our universe is barely even born. Could you imagine if every second of your life was the experience of a whole universe of time? How many universes have you spent taking a shit? Possibly millions. If you spend only 2 minutes per day taking a shit, then after a hundred years, you shitted out 4.3 millions universes / seconds.

You can still use the energy of the black holes in the blackhole epoch. At that point the background radiation is colder than the blackhole radiation, thus you can use that energy to power digital people for 10^100 years or so, especially since at those cold temperatures, electronics become much much more efficient. And then you can use the last exploding energy of the blackhole to move around a black dwarf and use the energy of the atoms turning into iron. Again this is only possible due to the coldness of the universe at that age, thus electronics become much more efficient.

By the point in time that white dwarves die, humans will either be extinct, or be so advanced that they'll have basically transcended to a higher state of existence. Whether that entails physical forms that never age, converting ourselves into digital forms with a near infinite power supply, or quantizing ourselves into a form that transcends the laws of physics as we know them, it'll certainly be a long way off, but it'll keep us alive in a dead universe. It'll be a lonely existence, and entropy dictates that something will go wrong and kill us off eventually anyway, but it'll mean that sentient races will be the last thing to go.

If we make it that far, then it will mean our species survived for trillions of years, longer than out universe has even existed yet, and was able to survive past the death of the universe. It would be an awe-inspiring legacy, but there's be nobody to leave it to. Nobody would be around to read the final chapter in our history.

One cannot measure distances of greater than about 25 light-years using parallax since we don't know EXACTLY where (not only does the Earth go around the sun, the sun orbits the galactic center, etc. so determining exactly where Earth was 180 days ago is all the more difficult) the Earth was sixth months ago using the Earth's ORBIT around the sun as the base of the triangle. Just ONE light-year has an angle of ONLY 0.017 degrees already! If u think Red Shift measures/accurately gauges distances 2 distant objects, u need 2 know that red shift is QUANTIZED (only at certain energy levels), absolutely ruling out the Dopper Effect explanation, may b caused by tired light, (Light may lose energy naturally as it travels and remember that since light has mass, it is affected by other objects with mass. A solar sail works because light has momentum and therefore mass. If you believe light has energy, and energy is mass according to Einstein, then you believe light has mass.) objects moving @ right angles to us, & when gravity is acting on an object. There's this object moving TOWARDS us that is still red-shifted!!! There's this pair of objects connected with radically different redshifts that proves the big bang wrong. In addition, in the Virgo Cluster of galaxies, near the center, where the velocities are extremely high, the red-shift is somehow washed out. This strongly implies that strong motion DESTROYS the redshift, instead of creating it. A galaxy has even been measured to have a DECREASE of one quantization in redshift, which should be impossible if the universe is expanding and the redshift is due to the doppler effect. YouTube: Stretching the Heavens: A New Cosmology. Google Science vs Evolution Pathlights. We can barely make out PLUTO with our best telescopes and yet we are told astronomers have detected a planet 1,300 or so light-years away?! Think about it. The object MAY be thousands of light-years away but we cannot measure those distances. We are simply TOO TINY, to put it humbly. And yes, there may be no such thing as deep space. Perhaps the "far away" objects are just super-tiny. It's possible. How could we know the difference? The Cosmic Background Radiation is much too cold to have come from the supposed Big Bang. It actually comes from stars. Be mindful that even after the "final" death of the Universe (entropy maximised), there will still be the phenomenon of transient virtual pair production, so I wonder how long that might continue (maybe for a VERY long time). Also, there's the problem of vacuum energy, and the (theoretical, at least) conclusions suggesting that our "vacuum state" is not a true vacuum, so there might still be (very considerable) "stores" of energy available.How about the concept of "Quantum Foam", where each "bubble" can behave like an entirely self-contained Universe - an extension of the Multiverse concept? There's plenty more strangeness "out there" waiting for discovery (or a browse courtesy of your favourite search engine!)

"One of the ways the universe can be illuminated is if two carbon–oxygen white dwarfs with a combined mass of more than the Chandrasekhar limit of about 1.4 solar masses happen to merge. The resulting object will then undergo runaway thermonuclear fusion, producing a Type Ia supernova and dispelling the darkness of the Degenerate Era for a few weeks.[23][24] If the combined mass is not above the Chandrasekhar limit but is larger than the minimum mass to fuse carbon (about 0.9 M☉), a carbon star could be produced, with a lifetime of around 106 (1 million) years.[13] Also, if two helium white dwarfs with a combined mass of at least 0.3 M☉ collide, a helium star may be produced, with a lifetime of a few hundred million years.[13] Finally brown dwarfs can form new stars colliding with each other to form a red dwarf star, that can survive for 1013 (10 trillion) years,[22][23] or accreting gas at very slow rates from the remaining interstellar medium until they have enough mass to start hydrogen burning as red dwarfs too. This process, at least on white dwarfs, could induce Type Ia supernovae too.[25]"

Uhm, yeah, Black holes can still explode and release energy, which can then re-form into new stars. Even once all the black holes are evaporated and if protons did decay, that wouldn't be it. Quantum mechanics doesn't allow for it. Eventually, a second big bang from a simple freak quantum chance will occur, and the universe will live forever.

I have always taught that Life was a game...a Perma-Death one yes...but STILL a game. Then I started thinking what if Life is NOT just a Perma-Death game but a whole cycle of respawning (sort of). What I'm trying to say is basically there is us your basic boring human living in a vast semi-crowded Universe with unknown to us beings that are probably not human who (all of us) have a timer until the Universe dies (DUH) and you've all probably heard of the Expansion Theory where everything gets so far away from each other that it's impossible for us to even reach the moon (if there even is one) right well the idea is yeah everything is faraway from each other but its still resembles a ring (Imagine it) and in the middle of that ring another Big Bang happens. So we all know that the Big Bang was this HUGE explosion with a shit ton of force which in our case is basically Doomsday but what if the meaning of life is to survive this Big Bang cycle and continue our lives in this new universe until it happens again. The only evidence I have of this theory to even slightly be possible is - HD 140283. yes I know it's sounds absurd  but it might have happened when you think about it but IT IS still just a theory that I have had and one that I recently wanted to share lel :P.

Imagine a technological species arising in the Degenerate Era.
The era of stars is already over.
Our Local Group of galaxies has long coalesced into one giant elipictical behemoth.
The expansion of the universe renders all light from beyond this galaxy invisible
as it is redshifted so much.
You would have no way of telling the age of the universe or even knowing of inflation.
The only stars created are red dwarfs, which will occasionally come into being
as two low-mass brown dwarfs collide.
Only about 100 of them will shine at all times as those stellar collisions will be fairly rare.

The sky above you would be totally dark, except for your system's planets.
And if you ever do stumble across the manner of detecting radio and infrared,
you will find the heavens littered with cooling stellar corpses in every direction.
You will then realise to be one of the very last living worlds to ever exist.
One of the last bastions of against the unrelenting storm that is entropy.

Now, that realization is what one may call existentialist crisis...

Technically though, I think we have shown that bacterial life can survive the enormous acceleration due to gravity, so it might be possible for a near-black dwarf to support a limited biosphere when it cools to Earthlike temperatures. In fact, for all I know, the chemical environment around one in trillions of years might be highly conducive to life.
Well if humanity expands there technology in the far far future we might be able to make our own stars possibly.

One big problem with using a near-black dwarf as a heat source is getting close enough. If, for example, you were to enter low orbit around one, you'd be in a gravitational field that changes so quickly that objects are vertically stretched and horizontally compressed at on the order of a m/s^2/m.

That is quite problematic for building anything. It means, for example, that a 20-meter-high orbiting structure would have 1 Gee of gravity on the floor and -1 on the ceiling.

Incredibly beautiful and emotive video. Please let me point out a minor detail. Galaxies are not supposed to evaporate or anything. Each galaxy remains forever as a collection of black dwarfs and black holes inside its dark matter halo, isolated from the rest of the Universe by the accelerated expansion, but does not evaporate or anything until those objects evaporate (or dark matter is annihilated in some unknown process). a few note: Black holes will emit hawking radiation well beyond that time and while its not an overly massive energy output, some scientists have proposed that as our last energy refuge. 2: A time scale of "more or less forever" opens up an interesting window of opportunity for quantum effects to have a macroscopic influence. 3: it may be possible for us to leave, the jury is still out on wormholes. 4: It's a bit of a semantic cop out but the universe isn't a closed system in the conventional sense. This doesn't actually provide a reason for heat death to not work but does imply a need for at least some caution in our assumptions about how it ot works on such time scales.

Theres some things worth considering here. From what we know about systems its extremely improbable but also inevitable over infinite time that a system will reach its initial state again. It's also worth pointing out that going back to the big bang means that at some point the initial state is uniform. Which means every other state of any local state exists in every variation somewhere else in the universe (assuming its infinite in size). Entropy just states that there will a particular combination in the way all of these interact with each other. There's also nothing that absolutely says we must be trapped in this universe if we're in a multiverse.

Human nature.. ooh poor, ignorant children. Our whole history is but a grain of sand in the vast continuum of time. We are like the morning dew trying to piece together the vastness and complexity of the ocean. Like a bacterium attempting to expose the grandiose scheme of infinity. The deepest, most dillusional form of absolute ignorance stems from claiming we have even an atoms worth of knowledge or intelligence to understand the unfathomable complexities of reality. Claiming to know when our universe will "die" and putting a number on it is ignorance to the greatest extent. If a bee can spend its whole life living amonst us humans, yet never come close to understanding even a fraction of a percent of all our civilization, how can you expect that humans, who have been here for the most perplexingly minute amount of time, would be able to contemplate, let alone make reasonable assumptions about a universe so large that no number can define its distance. A placeholder known as "infinity" is used to describe it when we have no conception of what this word actually means. How can we see the whole picture when our eyes are closed? Can a blind man concieve color? We are absolutely wasting our blip of time, trying to uncover secrets that are outside our ability to understand. Like trying to shove the whole of the universe and all of time into our brains that can hardly stay focused on one task for a few minutes. Logic was created as a tool by something much, much larger. Imagine a saw, which only knows one thing; how to cut, and it tries to use that knowledge to reverse engineer how a house is built. You see, we are a tool, and reverse engineering the thing that created us lies completely outside of our capacity. We are like water trying to burn. Like a stone attempting to fly. Pray to God, the creator, for wisdom. He will bring you hope, freedom, and peace. Do not listen to fools who say they know the fate of the universe. For it is easy for a fool to say he "knows," especially when your life is too short to even reach the conclusion to see whether or not he was right. There is no such thing as "the end". If stars are burning now it is apparent that a force unknown to us set the cycle in motion, and has the power to reset the cycle by desire. Peace. Jesus loves you.

Fact: A neutron star is formed when a star of at least 4 times the mass of our sun runs out of hydrogen to fuse. Then helium begins to fuse (followed by carbon, magnesium etc. until it finally reaches iron (element with the highest binding energy)) burning the outer hydrogen causing it to expand into a red supergiant. When the star begins producing iron in the core it no longer creates fusion energy as iron will not fuse and so the outward radiation pressure is no longer equal to the inward gravitational pressure which causes the red supergiant to become unstable. If the core of the star has a mass that is greater than 1.4 times the mass of our sun (the Chandrasekhar limit) then the electron degeneracy rule is overcome by the immense gravitational pressure causing electrons to fuse with protons creating neutrons (hence neutron star). The outer layers of the red supergiant come rushing in and shoot back outwards in a massive supernova explosion. The core of the star remains as the neutron star. Additionally, if the neutron star has a mass that is greater than 3.2 times the mass of our sun then its gravitational force become so great that light can no longer escape it. When this occurs the star will become a black hole. A neutron star is so dense that one teaspoon of material from a neutron star is as heavy as all the cars, buses and trucks on earth put together!

What if humanity could create an artificial star? Within a billion billion years, if humanity is still progressing as it is now, we would potentially be well, well past even a type III civilization, maybe even a type IV. We could have achieved omnipotence, if that's the case we wouldn't need a source of energy to survive, if omnipotence is impossible or still out of our grasp, as long as humanities technological progress is still advancing we could easily create a new star, potentially even resurrect the universe. Manipulate gravity on a universal scale, potentially even a multiverse. We have achieved quantum computing and particle colliders within the 200 years since the industrial revolution, with a billion, billion years, it would not be far fetched to assume that humankind has stretched throughout the known universe; even further. This is assuming three things.

We had not been obliterated by ourselves/disease/extraterrestrial sources etc... (potential but low probability)
We are alone in the Universe (unlikely)
The laws of physics can be broken (potential, the laws of physics technically are not backed by some confirmed fundamental laws, just based on [very limited] research).

If we are not alone (at least with intelligence that rivals/is superior to our own) we will likely never completely rule over the universe due to rivalries and ethics. Conflict between rivalling civilizations will hinder progress and potentially mean the end to humanity, but what will probably happen is like the currenr situation with USA and Russia. The two civilizations will progress at a similar rate and neither one will have complete dominance; at least not for a while. Ethical issues may occur also, not interfering with the progress of other civilizations, wiping out other races to ensure/enhance the progression of our own, these issues will also hinder progress.

Probably the most important factor in our control of the universe would be the ability to manipulate/break the laws of physics. An ability such as not being able to break the speed of light or propulsion without propellant or a source of fuel. The ability to traverse the universe at speeds faster than light is essential for space exploration and control. Light itself is too slow to traverse the universe, taking millions of years to do so. Propelling ourselves across the universe would require speeds many millions of times faster than light to be efficient. Teleportation would be quicker than ftl propulsion, but you would need to be able to make data flow quicker than light aswell. Teleportation is not instant.

Propulsion without propellant requires thrust without fuel, this is essentially impossible, but nevertheless the Electromagnetic Drive can produce a reasonable amount of thrust (about 2x faster than a convential Ion drive) without any propellant, utilizing electrons bouncing around in a chamber to produce thrust. Fuel could be artificially created to supply a limitless amount, providing limitless energy is possible.

These are many of the hurdles in the way of humanity, but someday we might get there.

A distant dream.

So where does the energy go?  Mass/energy must be conserved.  If it doesn't leave the universe, and it shouldn't, it must be somewhere.        A campfire burns out because it runs out of energy.  The heat is transferred to the surrounding environment through convection, conduction, and radiation until eventually you just have ashes that are the same temperature as the surrounding environment.             So when the last white stars are dying out what happens to the energy they have been emitting all their lives, along with the energy emitted by every star that ever lived.  If we were around at that time, would everything look lit up from all the light traveling around.  Or does it all eventually get scarfed up by black holes?  Leaving nothing but black dwarves with no energy and black holes with lots of gravity?         But even black holes evaporate via Hawking radiation, so they will be emitting energy too, very slowly, for a long time until they have completely evaporated to nothing.  Then what is all that energy doing?         So it seem that when the universe finally "dies", it will still have plenty of energy, but it will be flying through space and most of it won't be interacting with anything.  Black dwarves will be hit by this energy and will be heated up a little, which they should emit until they reach some sort of equilibrium where the energy a black dwarf emits equals the energy it receives.  This then will be the last and stage of the universe.  There should be no change from this state.         Just guessing.  I'm not a physicist.

I once challenged my science class.
We had been learning about the universe and such, and I had the topic of dark matter on my mind.
I asked my Science teacher this- If we consider nothing air, but empty as space, why do we call nothing "nothing?" Dark Matter / Energy is considered "Nothing beyond Empty," but it is still composed of something. If nothing really is nothing, then is it less than "empty" space? Forsay we empty both substances from ANY form of life, geographic like stars or biologically like humans. Would this empty "Empty" space still be less than nothing? If we consider nothing as a figure replaced by air, is it truly less than nothing?
In result of asking this, though, my class called me dim witted and dumb. They told me that nothing is just a name, and that dark matter didn't exist. Even my teacher disgruntled me, by simply replying "No" without giving any thought.
We'll figure out how to reverse entropy eventually.

Great visuals, as always, but flawed science.  This is the dinosaur paradigm of star formation and activity.  It is becoming increasingly clear that stars actually function as a kind of electrical capacitor for charged plasma moving along channels called Birkeland currents.  The inside of a star actually appears black beneath both coronal holes and sunspots because it is much cooler than the corona.  There is no hydrogen fusion deep in the star which powers it; the sun is a focal point, a 'z pinch', in a current filament which supplies a constant charge that effectively 'powers' the star.  This, hopefully, will be not only completely proven out in my lifetime but accepted and actively studied by scientists and scholars rather than rejected outright without proper scientific inquiry.

Of course, there's another possibility: Entropy will reverse. Something had to give rise to the universe, likely energy arising from the quantum foam - something from nothing - which itself has many possible explanations from quantum membranes to the will of gods with no one knowing for sure what really set it all in motion. All we do know is that there had to be a process, and that process - whatever it may be - can happen again if it has happened before. Perhaps when the universe expands enough energy from other dimensions will be able to flow in, through a properly similar in function to thermodynamics but via some unknown process. Or maybe the process of expansion will reverse, also known as a "big crunch", or maybe a new big bang will form without there ever needing to be a big crunch. Truth is, we really don't know.

If there are other universes though, and if there is any process that can allow energy to pass between by any natural process, it would mean that humans could travel to younger universes in the event of this worst case scenario. Or maybe humans will die with the Earth having never met their potential. Who knows?

Cool Video, Kurzgesagt. However, I am not so sure about humanity being able to colonize a tidally locked planet. As I understand it, the small zone where liquid water could exist will be mobile, meaning that if humanity did exist there, they would have to keep moving their colonies. A space station orbiting the star seems more likely to work IMHO. This is also why I think it unlikely that life will be discovered on tidally locked planets, as the zone for liquid water would be mobile, effectively freezing for poaching any life, given enough time.

But what about black holes and hawking radiation? Wouldn't it theoretically be possible to collect the absurdly low-power but still existing energy black holes and other event horizons radiate? And by extension, use black dwarves as a 'fuel' to ditch into a black hole to prolong its lifetime and eventually convert the entirety of the available matter into energy?

Surely if energy is relative to matter there will still be a trickle of usable energy being released into the surroundings or we could use the remnants of stars for energy ourselves. Heck, if we live long enough for black dwarfs to exist we can probably harness the iron for something.

This end-of-universe nihilism stuff is bothersome to me. As long as there is a species like us that is around to grow technologically, there are a bunch of requirements that must be met for the universe to truly end.

1. Younger big bangs too distant or too unlikely to find. (Flying though pure darkness at many multiples of C looking for just one photon of light emitted from a different big bang, possibly never finding it.)
2. Impossible to ever find a way to pull matter, antimatter or energy, out of the quantum fields, sustainably. (The quantum fields are at extremely high energy levels when their part of spacetime are devoid of energymass.)
3. Never develop a method to seed an artificial big bang. (We've got some pretty good theories as to what caused ours, eventually we may implement our own.)
4. Never develop the ability to exist ethereally. (If there IS something to the spark of conciousness, spirits, or souls, then this should eventually be doable.)

For anyone that doesn't know Tidally locked planets are when it rotates and revolves at the same speed. This causes one side to face the star constantly giving it light 24/7 while the other side is facing away from light making it night 24/7. I forgot but I'm pretty sure this effect is due to gravity but you will have to check on that. A good example of this is our moon. We only see one side of our moon through all of its phases. I like all these videos a lot. However, please don't pretend that science is set in stone. Especially the end of the universe. The exact workings the universe are not properly understood and therefore neither is its ending. This is totally open for revision. It also does not take into account the effect that that life might have on the process. As of now, no life can make any difference on cosmic events. However, given the seemingly ever accelerating progress that human kind is making, who knows what we will be able to do in 100 years, 1000? a million? Billions of years?
Good luck future life!

Actually, I would say stopping at that point is wrong. That process you're talking about takes approximately 10^1500 years. The next process (quantum tunnelling into black holes, then hawking radiating away) should take around 10^100000000000000000000000000 years. Then eventually, everything turns into protons, neutrinos, and electrons, and is spread so far apart in the universe they are untouchable and at 10^-30 degrees kelvin. Nothing happens from there until the end of time. Unless you believe in random fluctuations, which say that any particle, no matter how long, will eventually do something (ie, ice boiling at 0 degrees Celsius, the chances of it happening, at so close to zero it's almost impossible, but imagine that with 2 random particles with no gravity, randomly hitting despite being billions of km apart and perfectly still just before. It's basically saying, if you wait infinitely long, eventually it'll happen. A hydrogen atom will be made, and then decay, and go back to that same infinite state, but eventually, there will be stars and galaxies, and people. One day, some other random will be writing this same message on this same video who looks just like me.

White dwarf   <del>> .. Once fusion power dies ..  Star start to collapse inwards (due to gravity) .. the election degeneracy pressure kicks in and stop the contraction (Depends on Size of star -</del> which is called chandrasekhar limit .. upto1.4 Solar Masses) and we end up in a new state of star .. called White dwarf ..  If size of star would have been above chandrasekhar limit .. then even electron degeneracy pressure can no longer hold contraction and we end up in new state .. Neutron Star, pulsar or magnetar (Massive Stars which fail to produce black hole or end up being neutron star) or Black hole (if mass is too huge)

Everything in the Universe, even the laws of nature themselves, consist of energy in the form of fields. Take the gravity field (negative energy), or the electromagnetic field, for example. If entropy is the problem that leads to the heat death of the Universe (which is constantly expanding),

then all we need to do to reverse entropy and sustain the universe, possibly forever, is to find a way to convert the energy inherent in the nature of space itself into usable energy and use that to create the matter we need to sustain ourselves. Basically we'd shrink space itself, locally, in order to obtain whatever we need. Meanwhile the universe, because of entropy and the effects of the big bang, keeps expanding. We wouldn't need to go anywhere, we'd just "eat" the very nature of existence itself and shepherd this universe until we grow tired of it or go someplace else. Like a spider, sitting in the center of its web, pulling its old threads back into its mouth and converting it back into new web.

Asimov once wrote a short story 'The Last Question'. In it, humanity creates a computer that can answer all questions given enough time. Over the course of milennia humans colonize the entire universe and only live in machines, existing practically as minds wandering through time. Eventually, the only question remaining is how to stop the heat death. The computer can't think of the answer in time and the universe dies along with the humans. After an eternity, he finds the answer, but there's no one left to tell it. So it just says 'Let there be light' and there was light.

There is a way to allow our sun to burn brightly forever. Imagine a device that could pull out any element heaver than hydrogen and would cleanly split those elements back into hydrogen. Then the device would spit the hydrogen plasma back into the star, thus giving it an near infinite life span. Furthermore this device could be powered by the plasma it pulls from the sun.

However this device would be so massive and would require a tractor beam that could pull specific elements from a soupy mixture of plasma made up a various elements, and a device that could cleanly split atoms back into hydrogen.

This device would work for a time as over millions of years dust, comets, asteroids, and various other materials have been pulled into that star due to its gravity.

You can also farm off black holes!
Super-massive black holes have enormous amounts of rotational energy you can tap off of and live like kings until that's gone. The neat thing about that is that you have to actively rob the black hole's momentum tidally, so it's a fixed energy amount you can tap and go through gradually at your own discretion.

Also, the other way to get energy out of a black hole is hawking radiation. If you can manage to eek by on the obscenely small stream of hawking radiation energy coming off a super-massive; you could conceivably exist for much longer than you could on white dwarf light.

I'm sorry, but I refuse to accept the notion that our universe will become permanently dead with no chance for recovery. The universe was dark, dead, and empty before until the Big Bang, wasn't it? What's stopping something like the Big Bang from happening again?
What If we made our own stars

There is still one last hope after white dwarfs. It may be possible to harness the rotational energy of black holes. This could grant life, or whatever passes for it eons into the future, more time. As far as we understand it, all the galaxies in our supercluster should merge, and that single, central black hole will be the last source of known rotational energy.

Perhaps all surviving life forms will all cluster around this last source of energy, and, to extend existence, will put themselves into an ancestor simulation. Maybe it will be a simulation of a time when the universe was young and their were still stars and unbridled possibilities. Maybe we are in such a simulation right now.

I'm an optimist though. Yes, our chances of being born into a universe with stars is infinitesimally small, and most of the universe's existence is a time without stars. Still, I still feel it's unlikely any human or our successors would want to simulate this time period. Consider that today, few humans would want to simulate living in the ancient world, with all its social problems like slavery, war or diseases, and I think that analogy should hold true for the future. I feel our best days are still ahead of us.

If we are alive in a trillion years we will surely have found a solution to all of that, maybe going to a parallel universe or having a machine that travels faster than light build "solar panels" or other more efficient technology that will be able to absorb all the energy from most stars of the universe so that when they die, we'll have saved 99.9% of the usable light they gave.
Even better, we'll find a way of simply making energy out of nothing which I think will be pretty easy eventually, probably using particles that pop in and out of existance or breaking the rules with a parallel universe "wall" that has different laws of physics and we can make energy out of nowhere there.
I mean, by 1903 we build the first plane. 54 years later we had sent the sputnik to the space. And 12 years later we went to the moon.
17 years ago the first USB Stick had a little over 1MB of memory. Now there are MicroSD the size of a pinky fingernail of 256GB
And given exponential technological advance, we probably will reach 256TB USBs in... about 10 years, maybe?
I mean, there even is a chance we might reach immortality before I die.
Now we are not talking about 10 years of time to fix all those problems, we are talking about trillions of years. It would be pretty disappointing if we couldn't do anything about it. I say there are two possible outcomes
1. We'll prevent the universe from heat death.
2. We'll have transcended that and we will be in a different universe by then.

If not, we will be extinct already (hopefully not)

Mars is better off being harvested for Iron than living on. It's gravity is too weak for humans without artificial gravity machines, which by that point we can use Megastructure Space Stations for artificial gravity anyway. It also has no magnetosphere, which means it will require a an artificial one, which still points to Space Stations being a better home.

I think the idea of the world staying in that dark phase of absolute entropy forever is provably wrong. Eventually a massive quantum tunneling will occur, massive enough to create a new BIG BANG and start a new generation of expanding galaxies and eventually, new stars. This may seem impossible, quantum tunneling is rare and to imagine it at such a scale appears  absurd, but only until one considers the amount of time that will be available. Everything possible, no matter how unlikely, will happen in infinite time. I have heard this incredibly rare phenomenon that is none the less bound to happen in the fullness that is encapsulated in "forever" called a "quantum miracle".

It's entirely possible our descendants, or those of another species, will manage to find a way to escape the heat death of the universe or even prevent it. Our science still has lightyears to go and if we've proven anything up until this point, it's that we are great at improvising and bending nature to our advantage.

I see no reason why entropy, which is, after all, only a statistical occurrence happening in a closed system, couldnt be stalled, stopped or reversed at will, in a variety of ways. For instance, what if the universe isnt a closed system? What if we could funnel energy in from another universe? What if we could create energy from subspace and use that to build the hydrogen and helium atoms to form new suns? My whole point is, stop presenting the fate of the universe as though it's written in stone and as though we have figured out more than the basics of universal laws, because it isn't and we haven't. Much love.

If we exist as a species for billions of years, and the universe does end up with a heat death, well, by that time, we should find ways to kickstart new stars with methods which use physics we have no clue about currently, for example, the smaller structures we break, the more energy output we get, what would happen if we manage to break subatomic particles at a large, but still usable scale? Could we learn to influence quantum fluctuations to create new particles? There are so many ways we could proceed, it seems highly unlikely we could go extinct if our species spreads throughout the galaxy. By that time, we should be perfectly capable of finding new ways to escape death. Hell, if a thing is concievable, it is usually doable, just it might not be easy to get there, we just need to hope that either our species lasts long enough, or our current understanding of physics sucks, and the universe can replenish itself by means unknown to us, or both, that would be the ideal!
